channel.title: Securely Deleting Files
channel.description:
When you delete a file through the recycle bin it doesn't actually delete it, it just hides it and keeps a reference.
My question is: If you use a recovery tool to get the file back and then securely delete it (write over the space with random 0s and 1s) will it write over the file you originally deleted through the recycle bin or does the recovery tool make a copy of the file you deleted and then securely delete that, meaning the original file that was deleted still exists?
It's a bit hard to understand but its the best I can do. Thanks
EDIT: SEE POST 3 FOR MORE INFO

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

nade:

Open that file, replace all data with other characters - save. Is decent enough. I don’t think any commercial data recovery software will be able to show you the previous data.

Firstly, there is no guarantee that when you do that the file editor isn’t just saving it as a new file, deleting, and renaming, in fact, many do that, so it would be no better than deleting. (perhaps worse, because you don’t know if it just deleted it)

Secondly, I think fancy commercial data recovery like that available to law enforcement forensic labs and such will most certainly be able to recover at least something, since, even if a file is over-written, sometimes there are magnetic remains left behind to gather some information from, this is why ‘secure deletion’ utilities generally write over that area of the disk hundreds or thousands of times with random data, hoping all traces are deleted.

Read full topic

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @nade nade
item.description:
@nade wrote:

Open that file, replace all data with other characters - save. Is decent enough. I don’t think any commercial data recovery software will be able to show you the previous data.

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:9, topic:387047”]Long story short, NTFS uses a paging file which references every file on your system. When you delete a file, you’re merely removing the reference from the paging file.

In short, you should be able to use a file recovery application to find the deleted file, and then remove it properly from there by doing several passes over the area of disk that the file is stored on (ie, writing 0s).[/quote]

That’s exactly what I needed, thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Long story short, NTFS uses a paging file which references every file on your system. When you delete a file, you’re merely removing the reference from the paging file.

In short, you should be able to use a file recovery application to find the deleted file, and then remove it properly from there by doing several passes over the area of disk that the file is stored on (ie, writing 0s).

Read full topic

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:6, topic:387047”]windows implements object reuse protection, which means that when an app allocates virtual memory, or file space, it is unable to look at the data that was previously stored in the resources windows allocated for it. or at least i think so.

try looking here for the program to securely remove the files: http://www.zdnet.com/blog/storage/how-to-really-erase-a-hard-drive/129

p.s. stop looking at so much child porn[/quote]

Never have and never will, my laptop is going in to get fixed and I don’t want anyone seeing personal files. and Thanks.

Read full topic

try looking here for the program to securely remove the files: http://www.zdnet.com/blog/storage/how-to-really-erase-a-hard-drive/129

p.s. stop looking at so much child porn

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

Use a magnet. Whenever I am paranoid about the police coming and taking my HDDs I just swipe a few neodymium magnets over my HDDs.

Read full topic

item.title: Securely Deleting Files
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

I know its a bit complicated, sorry.

I want to know how to securely delete files which I have already deleted through the recycle bin.

At the moment I use Eraser or Wipe depending on which OS I’m using but these only work for files which I haven’t deleted yet.
These programs write 0s and 1s to the hard drive in the space which the file I’m deleting occupies, to make it unrecoverable.

My first post basically says “If I recover a file using a file recovery tool, then delete it with eraser or wipe, can it then be recovered?”

Thanks

Read full topic

My question is: If you use a recovery tool to get the file back and then securely delete it (write over the space with random 0s and 1s) will it write over the file you originally deleted through the recycle bin or does the recovery tool make a copy of the file you deleted and then securely delete that, meaning the original file that was deleted still exists?
